div1.p: To Give Credit Where It Is Due

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, Baltimore American, July 6, 1912
div1.p:
TO GIVE CREDIT
WHERE IT IS DUE

DR. JENKINS TO WRITE BOOK
ON YELLOW FEVER.

To Gather Facts Concerning Con-
vention Held Here Years Ago, at
Which Two Physicians Declared
That Yellow Fever Was Not
Contagious, But Was Infected
Through Some Other Means--He
Searches The American Files.

Dr. William T. Jenkins at one time
health commissioner of New York city
and also health officer of that port, was
in the city yesterday searching for rec-
ords of the Second National Sanitary
Convention, which was held in Baltimore
in 1858. Dr. William Miller Kemp was
commissioner of health in Baltimore at
that time. He advanced a theory at that
congress that yellow fever was not con-
tagious. A resolution to that effect was
also offered by Dr. A. H. Stevens of
New York.

From observations these doctors had
found that yellow fever was not trans-
mitted by contagion, and a search was
then started to discover in what manner
the disease was spread. Their theory
was proven correct in 1899 by Dr. Wal-
ter Reed, of the United States Army.
who, with a party of doctors, went to
Cuba to make a study of yellow fever.
It was at that time the startling discov-
[line missing]
sponsible for the transmission of yellow
fever. Dr. Jenkins will publish a book
in which he will give Drs. Kemp and
Stevens credit for being the first men
to advance the theory that yellow fever
was not contagious. Dr. Jenkins spent
yesterday morning going through old
files of The American.

“There have been four National Sani-
tary Conventions held in the United
States,” said Dr. Jenkins. “The first
was held in Philadelphia in 1857: the
second in Baltimore in 1858: the third in
New York in 1859, and the fourth in
Boston in 1860. At these conventions
many important questions were discussed.
It was not known at that time that yel-
low fever was transmitted by the mos-
quito. Dr. A. H. Stevens, a noted phy-
sician of New York and one of the au-
thorities on sanitation in the United
States, offered a resolution at the con-
vention in Baltimore in 1858, in which he
advocated the theory that yellow fever
was not contagious. Dr. William Miller
Kemp, who was the commissioner of
health in Baltimore at the time, was
also a strong believer in Dr. Stevens'
theory. They did not know then that
it was the mosquito that carried the
dreaded disease. But from scientific ob-
servations they were positive that there
were other means than contagion for
spreading the disease.

“To prove this theory Dr. Kemp was
present when a ship was unloaded in
Baltimore that came from an infected
port. Some of the workmen who unloaded
the ship contracted yellow fever. That
ship must have brought mosquitoes from
the infected port, and they transmitted
the disease to the workmen. Dr. Kemp
did not know at that time that the mos-
quito was responsible for the transmission
of the disease, but he was positive that
there were no infected persons aboard
that ship and that the workmen con-
tracted the disease through some means
that had not been discovered by the
medical profession.”

Dr. Jenkins thinks that the men who
first advanced the theory should have
credit for what they did, as well as the
men who afterward proved their theories
correct.

“When the fourth convention met in
Boston in 1860,” continued Dr. Jenkins,
“no means had been discovered by which
ships could be disinfected. Steam was
afterward [fo]und to be the means that
had lon[g][word missing] sought by the scientific
[w]orld. [words missing] Harris, of New York,

[words missing] 1860. At the same time
[words missing] perfecting the use of steam
[words missing] purposes. I am writing a
book in which it is my intention to
give credit to such American doctors as
Dr. William Miller Kemp. of Baltimore;
Dr. R. H. Stevens, of New York, who
first advocated the theory that yellow
fever was not contagious, and to Dr.
Elisha Harris, of New York, who intro-
duced steam as a means of disinfecting
ships.”

Dr. William T. Jenkins was born at
Holly Springs, Mass., October 25, 1855,>
and was graduated from University of
Mississippi in 1878. He took a post-grad-
uate course at the New York University
in 1880, was appointed director of the
Merchant Marine Hospital Service for
Foreign Sailors in New York: health
commissioner of New York and officer
of the port, 1892 to 1894. He was coro-
ner's physician, 1881 to 1892. He is a
member of the County Medical Society
and Medical Association of New York.

While officer of the port of New York
Dr. Jenkins had charge of the Cholera
Hospital during the epidemic a number
of years ago.
